paragraphs.text: I’m pretty sure I used to read the same 3D way too. I’ve never really talked about it with anyone, kinda always assumed everyone reads the same way? Surprised to hear that they perhaps don’t? It rarely becomes that way these days though, but I feel that is pretty much because I pretty much never read for long stretches of time any more. Reading comes in small spurts, stuck between the other callings of life.

4e6ccc1353d9.title: I’m pretty sure I used to read the same 3D way too.

paragraphs.name: e993
paragraphs.text: I can still vividly imagine what I’m reading, but it slows me down. If I’m reading nonfiction or academic work, there’s just no need. Maybe it’s sad, but I even find myself irritated sometimes when I try to read fiction. “I can’t see where this is going,” I think, then remember that’s the point of fiction.

50fe61de7cb1.title: I can still vividly imagine what I’m reading, but it slows me down.

paragraphs.text: Wow — I really hope you succeed in your quest to find what it means to be immersed in this experience. I’ve been reading more lately, and I sometimes find myself in a trance of happiness and calm when I open a book that I like. Maybe these are the first steps towards being fully immersed in the story. Who knows — I hope you find out!

paragraphs.text: Never experienced 3-D immersive reading, but… I have experienced 3-D immersive writing! I wrote my first two stories when I was maybe 10 or 12 or 11. The first was about how you would get in your car, choose a destination on the screen, any destination at all, push the button and the car would take you there. I was in that car!

paragraphs.text: I stopped reading that way once I stopped looking at a book as some sort of magic, in it’s entirety

paragraphs.name: 2f7b
paragraphs.text: That’s interesting, Q. I can remember as a child seeing the books at the library as almost living things, like fairies or some other kind of magical being, like magic doorways just waiting for me to discover them and walk…

Thank you for writing this article. I enjoyed it immensely, and I also experience 3D immersive reading, and always have. Like you, I assumed everybody read that way. Now that I’m an adult, it doesn’t happen every time I read, but as some of the others here have suggested, it happens when certain factors are present in the writing. I would love to keep that part of my brain active, but I hadn’t put much thought into it until reading your story here. I am grateful for this app and everyone who contributes. Maybe I will work up the courage to submit something. You are an inspiration for me! Thank you.

paragraphs.name: 58cb
paragraphs.text: Well, I’ve always experienced reading in that way — and my mother did too. It didn’t disappear, but it now fluctuates, fighting with the critical in-brain editor that nags a lot. I hope you can return to reading with complete immersion, but I can tell you, it takes extremely good writing :)

paragraphs.name: edb1
paragraphs.text: So help me out, Medium friends. How do you experience reading? Has that experience changed over the years? Have you experienced 3-D immersive reading as described in this essay? Did it occur as a child or as an adult (or both)? Are you aware of books or programs that explore, and maybe even teach this kind of immersive reading?
